segments.text: I might have a good friend that I want to promote it, but his record is not as good as the others.
How in the hell can you promote him and have him embarrass you later because everybody's going to know who in the hell is on the board.
But if I've got a fellow that I know and he's got a good record and it's equal to all the others and I know him,
You remember, I'm a human being.
That's a guy that I'm probably going to select for promotion.
But I don't want to get in that sort of process.
I support the whole system.
I think it makes mistakes, but again, you're dealing with people, and I support it.
Well, let me ask you a question about your record.
According to your record,
you were promoted to Brigadier General 1 December 1965, and then underneath that it says Major General 1 July 65, which is earlier, and then under that it says promoted 1 October 69.
What is the situation there?
Let me see if I can explain that.
You've got an Army, Navy, and Air Force.
It ought to have a balance in the ranks, promotion this year.
Admirals this year in the Navy, rear admirals, two-star rear admirals this year, the two-star Air Force, and two-star Army all ought to rank from this year according to when they're promoted.
Okay?
In other words, you and I were on this year's list announced in December for promotion next fiscal year.
Okay?
You were number one on the list, I was number two.
Navy's got the same thing, number one and number two, and Air Force number one and number two.
General comparative ranks should be the same amongst the three of us, Army, Navy, and Air Force.
Yes, but this deals with the Navy, doesn't it?
Yeah, this deals with the Navy of one grade.
You see what I mean?
They go from zero to two stars.
So to balance that, that's what you do.
You backdate to a data rank.
You see my data rank?
Okay, well that explains it.
Okay, now in this position

this dual-purpose job which you had for three years, from August 62 to October 65, in this job, was it considered like a tour of duty, or would you have stayed there longer at the request of the Secretary of Defense?
Well, they try to respect.
is considered for a colonel and staff position a three-year tour is considered a complete tour duty.
I think mine was a little longer than that.
But that's at the request of the secretary.

You've described McNamara, now that I've heard some words about his so-called whiz kids that he brought into the Department of Defense, one of the attempts, of course, to make it more cost efficient, to streamline it.
Did you meet any of these people?
Who were they?
What did you think of them?
I'm trying to think of one of their
I can't think of his name now.
Well, let's put it this way.
I got along with him and worked with him, but I thought they were an egotistical anti-military bloc, generally speaking.
And you didn't think that of McNamara?
Uh, no.
I thought he was just anti-people.
And I accepted the fact that- You mean he was unsociable?
No, he just didn't think too much of people.
He thought people are just a bunch of, you know, they had no personal feelings or anything.
What I guess that I'm trying to say, he thought you could computerize people and just push a button and they'd all fall out, you know, and line up and so on and forth.
In no way in God's world you'll ever manage people.
You lead people, but you'll never manage them in the same sense as you manage blocks of wood, or tanks, or airplanes, and so on and forth, and manage the finance and the other aspects of life.
You just can't computerize the individualities of each guy.
and get a handle on management of all that.
That's what he, that was his major, that and the political, total disregard for the political side of democracy.
But you didn't care for the so-called whiz kids?
Oh, I got along with them.
I don't think they made a contribution.
I can tell you that they probably contributed to the political loss, as you may call it, of the Vietnam conflict.
I know of nothing that they did that made a contribution during that period of time.
They were the ones that was involved in having the war end
with not one tank, not one airplane, not one round of ammunition left.
Okay.
Let's talk about some of the interesting episodes during that Kennedy period.
One of course is Cuba.
Yeah.
Tell me about your dealings.
Cuba was a sort of thing that my boss and I
slept in the Pentagon during the intense days of that.

We were responsible for the reserve call-up, which was against my better judgment, but I was overruled because of the inadequacies that they, particularly the Army, were coming up with in order to go to
fight the war in Cuba.
Why were you against calling up the reserves?
I felt like that we ought to go do it with what we had in hand, and I felt that we were over exaggerating what we needed.
For example, why do you need to call up 300 or 400 reserve colonels to come in and supplement a staff that's already 25% overstrength in the Department of the Army?
Tell me why you want to do that.
Call them mobilization designees?
Why do you want to do that?
Why did they?
They didn't.
I denied that.
But they wanted it.
Why do you want to call up a truck company and you have no trucks and it has one truck?
What are you getting out of that?
Why do you call up the worst truck company you've got instead of calling up the best if you really need one?
Because of bad management and you don't know what the hell you've got.
And it exposed to the world the inadequacies
of our army particularly in its management and knowing the readiness and what it has in the reserves.
It was so bad and so embarrassing to us as a nation that I refused completely and did not get overruled on calling up the reserves for Vietnam until after I had left there.
somebody come in and call them up.
And, of course, the units that they called up never got themselves in shape to go.
And they called up very few.
Yeah, very few.
Now, they called up Signal Company.
They called up
amphibious truck companies and all this sort of stuff with no trucks and people.
And what did they do?
And no equipment to give them.
It's a total disaster.
And that's the reason why I didn't want this done.
I knew the status of our reserves.
And so why do you want to do that?
Well, it was the most embarrassing episode of our time in this decade, I believe, from the standpoint of the military.
Next to Mr. Carter's Iranian disaster, where he's gonna go evacuate the

hostages now were you then were you as far as the manpower is concerned were you in charge or was one of your functions to help assemble that very large invasion force down in Florida only the reserve aspect the other part that we are deeply involved in is seeking manpower requirements totally and

control of manpower cornerments and what do you bring out of the what do you call up and web individuals do you allow the cuban conflict to pull all the school teachers and the lawyers and the doctors out of one village or out of that one part of the country and so on and forth to support that conflict down there or do you go ahead and try to do it without being disruptive to the whole of our society or where do you declare a national emergency and

and call up everybody and put a package of legislation national emergency legislation that high and I had a lot of it that government controls goes on pricing and housing transportation air gasoline food services the whole thousand things would be totally disruptive for the whole of our society because you got a little old
conflict down here that you ought to clean up in about ten days?
The answer is no, but you've got to justify that by a lot of facts and data which you spend a lot of hours putting together to support your position.
Was your opinion in a Cuban Missile Crisis that it would be a
During those days, during those very tense days, you said that you were sleeping at the Pentagon.
Yes, sleeping in my office, yes.
Tell me about the feelings there, the tension.
How were the people?
How were they behaving?
Did they feel war was winning?
A lot of us knew what hour we were going to go.
What do you mean?
Oh, we were within hours of blowing the whistle.
Went at 10 o'clock one Sunday morning.
The president got a call over the hotline from Khrushchev and said, I'll move them out.
And goddamn, we were worried about the Pentagon.
phones down at JCS in the operations room.
My boss buzzed me on the phone.
He said, don't you think we ought to go home?
It's Sunday.
I said, well, I'm ready.
Let's go.
Who was your boss?
Norm Paul.
Oh, yeah.
So, we left, went home.
And then there was a collective sigh of relief?
I guess everybody gets worked up to these things.
You get ready to go, so what the hell difference it make, you know?
You know that?
Did you feel that America was prepared?
Well, we were about to sink Georgia and Florida.
Yeah, I said, God damn, we move one more truck down there, that damn place, those places are gonna sink.
Unloaded Fort Hood.
Damn, I said, I told Norm Paul one morning, I said, he said, we still have Florida underwater?
I said, no sir, not yet, but I said, boy, it's getting pretty damn high.
Did you have the plans made out for the invasion?
Oh hell, yeah.
You have contingency plans all the time.
Oh yeah, oh yeah.
Hell, we were ready to go.
We were ready to go.
Did you have any dealings whatsoever with the Bay of Pigs?
No, no.
and other organizations.
What about the early years of Vietnam when we were just starting to put in our advisors, getting them up to about 16,000 by the time of death?
I was responsible for coming up to President Johnson with a manpower plan for support conflict in Vietnam.
Oh, you were?
Yeah.
Mr. McNamara called Mr. Paul at 7 o'clock one evening.
I think this is about October or November of 1963 or 64, somewhere in there.
Probably 64, a year or so after the death of Kennedy.
Yeah, 64.
Bob McNamara called Norm Paul, and I was in with Norm Paul.
It was about 7 o'clock at night.
And Bob said to Norm, he said, Hey, Norm, I've got to have a plan, an entire plan to support conflict in Vietnam to the president at 9 o'clock in the morning.
said, uh, put an analyst on that and give me a plan for my signature as president by nine in the morning.
Norm said, uh, well the analyst is sitting right here with me.
And McNamara said, okay, go ahead and get that done for me.
I'll see it in the morning.
So I'd let my secretary back there, Virginia McGuire, and I'd send all my other officers, all colonels and captains from the Navy and the Air Force and Army.
You'd send them home?
Oh, they'd all go home.
I'd let them all go home.
Back there, Virginia McGuire, who was a favorite of Ms. Hollingsworth and one of the secretaries that I've had,
She was locking up the safes, and I said, get your book.
She said, what's all about?
I said, well, I said, we just got a requirement here we got to put together.
She said, I haven't been home before 9 o'clock in two weeks, and I don't even get a chance to wash my clothes.
I said, well, you can take care of that some other time.
I said, right now, get that safe open and get your book here.
I want to dictate to you the plan that's got to meet the president in the morning at 9 o'clock.
We finished it at 5 o'clock in the morning, about 18 pages.
And she said... And you did it yourself?
I did it myself.
How could you come up with it?
In other words, you had to...
I've been working on this stuff.
and you just had it on the top of your head.
Oh, yeah, I'd already thought about it, you know.
So, I said, Virginia, how do you like that?
She said, I believe that's the best one you've ever dictated.
And I said, well, you know, there's only one word that you've missed all night long.
And I said, we got about 18 or 20 pages.
I said, why don't you just go ahead and prepare.
I had the last page prepared for my initials, J-F-H.
And I had to lead Page into, for Secretary of Defense, through Assistant Secretary of Defense, manpower, subject, manpower support for Vietnam conflict, underlined, date, and so on.
I said, I'll tell you what to do.
Go in there and
change to get Mr. McNamara stationary now and put Memorandum for the President of the United States subject and re-type the last page and put Robert M. McNamara.
She said, you really feel confident about that?
Then when I get through, give me ten copies so we can finish this thing off.
Had the safes locked up.
I got in my car and went home.
I guess it was five o'clock.
I shaved five o'clock in the morning.
I shaved.
Woke Miss Hollingsworth up at 6.30 and said,
I'll try to get home earlier today, but I don't know what time.
I went back.
I belong to the Secretary of Defense at Miss.
I get back at 7 o'clock and here's my boss, Norman Paul.
Here's Dr. Foster, a director of research and engineering.
Here's Mr. Cyrus Vance, who is a deputy secretary of defense, former secretary of the army.

now former Secretary of State and here is Mr. Charlie Hitch who is a comptroller of the Defense Department and Mr. Tom Moore who is Assistant Secretary of Defense for Installations and Logistics and seemed like
There might have been one more assistant secretary there.

We were having breakfast and discussing usual subjects of common interest when Mr. Paul said, you know, Holly, we've got to get out of here and it must be 730 now and get this paper ready for Bob on that manpower
support plan.
I said, oh, I finished that at 5 o'clock this morning.
He said, you must be kidding.
I said, no.
He said, well, where is it?
I said, it's in this little package I got down here.
He said, let me see it.
I said, I got a copy for everybody here.
He started reading it.
Deputy Secretary of Defense started reading it.
I said, hell,

nothing wrong with this Mr. Charlie Hitch the comptroller who has to pay for all this said well let's take this paper and go see Bob right now they took my damn paper stamp top secret should be signed out you know by everybody back and forth everybody touching a long list of names whoever read it took my paper
Top secret.
I've never seen the paper again.
They delivered by McNamara to President Johnson.
He kept the paper.
That came the support plan that Mr. Johnson, the president, dictated back to the Defense Department to support, manpower support for Vietnam, JCS, Army, Navy, Air Force.
Nobody had chopped on it.
That's fantastic.
Yeah, that's the way things happen.
So it's basically your plan then for Johnson's call up?
It was his plan.
How he was going to support the manpower requirements for Vietnam.
That's incredible.

but that's some experiences you get involved in at the cabinet level and this is what makes this is what makes all the hard work and sacrifice that you may go through a time worthwhile you know to make a contribution you see to have a part in what the hell's happening in the management of our whole country and running of our whole country
That to me is worth spending a lot of hard days of study and hard work and everything else for.
To get yourself in a position where you make a contribution to do something.
Now at this time of course one of Matt and Amara's desires was to so-called streamline the military and to get rid of some of the
overlap that we had in each service.
For example, some of the supply in the supply area and the defense intelligence agency trying to set up one agency instead of having every service have their own agency.
Well, you know... How was your feeling toward the streamline?
Well, it's a matter of why should the Army

be buying 30 caliber ammunition and the Air Force 30 caliber ammunition and the Navy 30 caliber ammunition those are three procurement agencies and all three doing different all three different accountabilities systems and why don't you consolidate that and see if you can't get it all together cheaper more cost effective
and get better control of what the hell the requirements are, and better management.
And I agree with that.
I can't see why the Air Force has to have Granadas, and the Navy has to have Valiants, and the Army has to have Chevrolets.
And they may all pay a different price.
They have to stock all different kinds of spare parts.
Why don't you put that all together and let a procurement agency provide them with that capability, maybe get it cheaper and cut down on carrying three different kinds of spare parts.
Now this did raise some anger in military circles because some of the
Well, because of inter-service rivalry and because of some of the people who were moved or shifted around.

Like setting up the Defense Intelligence Agency, General Maples was in on that, and he said there were a number of people that were really irritated that each service was losing some of its intelligence capabilities for one centralized organization.
Did you...
Would you, I mean, did you hear a lot of grumbling?

Oh, I think, well, I think every time you change something, whether it's change for the better or change for the worse, there's nothing that, nothing in life amongst people that hurts worse than change.
That, that really...

that's really one of the worst things that can happen to people is change because some like it and some dislike it and when you get change in policies you get change in organizations people are going to they're split right down the middle on these things generally speaking and in the case of the intelligence group it's kind of

pull together, if you're the Secretary of Defense, you get one set of reports out of the Navy, another one from the Air Force, and another one from the Army, and maybe they're all three in this one particular instance reporting on the same thing, and you're getting three different reports.
So, what do you say?
You say, well, who in the hell am I supposed to believe in this damn thing?
Well, why don't we have somebody take what all three of them are reporting and don't let me have to go dig into each one of them to reconcile the differences.
Isn't there somebody else that can do that?
And I think this is what it's all about.
And we ended up with a lot of directorships, Defense Nuclear Agency, he became the key guy for all nuclear aspects of the Department of Defense.
Defense Supply, DSA, Director of Security Assistance Agency, he's responsible for all military sales.
DIA, Director of Intelligence Agency.
National Security Agency was already in existence, and it is a national level.
CIA is a national level.
NASA, a national level organization.
But they did put in those director areas, and I think that they made a hell of a good contribution myself.
Okay, now you said- Well, they have not denied, in the case of DIA-
the Army, Navy, and Air Force from having their own intelligence capability, which I think is very appropriate.
I have not denied that.
Now, you're on the cabinet level.
Did you attend cabinet meetings with Presidents Kennedy and Johnson?
No, Mr. McNamara

would only invite someone if there was a specific thing that he felt the presence of the individual would enhance his position in bringing about amongst the other cabinet members what he wanted to get done.
Same way with him appearing before Congress.
He would take a 250 or 300 page black briefing book and he'd go almost totally alone.
And he knew everything that was in that book and on what page it was.
He had a photostatic memory of that whole thing.

And when I would prepare something, a change that he wanted made, or a change would occur on a particular table or a page pertaining to manpower or reserves, I had to take that particular page up there, and he would look at it, the new one,
And he'd look at the old one, and he'd photograph the change I'd made, then he'd personally take out the old page and put the new page in his briefing book.
So he had photostatted, and you never had to worry about him coming back and saying he didn't tell me what the difference in this thing was.
Phenomenal fella.
Yes.
No.

You left that position in 1965 to go, well you had a position for just three months there, Office of the Deputy Chief of Staff or Personnel, and then you went to the Office of the Chief of Staff of the Army.
Well, I was on two boards.
I was on two boards.
One promotion board,
Oh, I see.
And one selection board for students to go to the Army, War College, National War College, to Britain, and Canadian War Colleges.
Those are just temporary?
Yeah, those are temporary before going to Vietnam.
Okay, so then you went to the 1st Infantry Division.
Right, I went to the 1st Infantry Division.
Let's start talking about that.
Had you volunteered for Vietnam?
Oh yes, I had volunteered for Vietnam about every six months since I prepared that manpower paper and I knew we were going to start to build up over there.
Continue now with Vietnam.
You said before lunch that you had tried to get over there.
You'd volunteered about every six months.
Yes.
And you finally made it.
What was your feeling about going back to war?
Well, I thought that we had an important responsibility over there, and I had no doubt about the fact that what I had seen in Washington there before the real
buildup came that we were going to do another piece of surgery on that country as we had done in Korea and stop the influx of communists from the north and also restore some sort of
government other than communism down in the South, as was the case in Korea.
That was a masterful act on the part of the United States to stop communism and separate the communists from the non-communists in North and South Korea, and I had hoped that that would be the
The same thing would be true in the case of Vietnam.
What were your responsibilities on this first tour?
My responsibility on the first tour was deputy commander for all military action and maneuver on the part of the 1st Infantry Division.
I was assistant division commander for maneuver, and maneuver means in the simplest terms for conducting the battles.
within the first division.
There's two assistant division commanders or two deputies to the major general, one for maneuver and the other one for supply, maintenance, logistics, support.
So, my responsibilities for maneuver was to
keep the troops ready to fight, keep them trained, conduct the battles, get involved in the planning for the battle, and then the execution of the plans when we were in battle.
And to oversee fire support, tactical air support,
coordination between the artillery and the tactical air, and the coordination, the movement, the airlifting of the battalions back and forth in the assault areas.
So it was a very busy time.
In addition to that, you are also involved in seeing how well people are trained and how well they're doing.
and try to correct the mistakes and errors that are being made oftentimes.
Some on the part of soldiers and officers who are not as trained as well as they ought to be.
So that's primarily what my responsibility was at that time.
And I was there about 15 months.
And where was the first division?
First division was in war zone.
three which encompassed Tainan Province.
It encompassed about eight or nine provinces north and west of Saigon near the Cambodian border.
And also touched on the Laos border, Laotian border.
Who was your general?
The division commander then was William E. Depew, D-E-P-U-A.
One hell of a great, fine fella.
Yeah, who later, who later, and we made quite a team, the two of us.
We worked very closely together and had a fine relationship.
And as a matter of fact, during the 15 months that I was in the division, we had one AWOL, one soldier went AWOL, that's all.
Only one?
Only one in 15 months.
In the whole division?
In the whole division.
In the whole division.
That's the kind of respect that we had from the soldier.
a remarkable sort of record.
But we stayed busy and when it came time to rest we left the soldier alone.
Let's talk about some of the operations that you had during these 15 months.
Well we had several, many.
We had I think one operation in which
We fought every regiment of the 9th VC Division, which was a key elite division.
But Operation Junction City, and that was in War Zone C, I guess it was, instead of 3, War Zone C. Tainan Province, Fook-Long Province,
north of Saigon in the Tainan, Quang Tri, Loc Nguyen, An Loc area.
And I think one of the most significant battles that points out how great America is is on the night of
March 1967, Troop A of the 5th U.S. Cavalry, which the 5th U.S. Cavalry belonged to the 9th Infantry Division, and the 9th Infantry Division were new in country.
And they were involved in opening and closing the road between a place called Lai Kei, which was the first division's base headquarters, and Quang Tri, which is up north, and a big rubber plantation.
opening the road and keeping it open so that supplies could get through to operating troops that had air assaulted into the areas.
And about midnight that night, a troop of the cavalry was in a wagon train formation, 125 little guys.
And they were hit at midnight with a heavy concentration of mortar fire and then assaulted from midnight until five o'clock in the morning by the 273 VC regiment.
And this is on Highway 13 just north of Ly-K.
This 273 Regiment had a strength of about 1,900 people and they attacked 125.
The message got to me about five minutes later in my headquarters at Ly-K, which wasn't very far from there,
This troop was being attacked.
As a matter of fact, they were assigned to the 1st Division at that time because all of the 9th Division hadn't gotten in.
And I immediately got airborne.

As a matter of fact, I was commanding the division at the time because General Depew had gone away on some other assignment on leave for two or three weeks and I was the senior and I was commanding the division.
I immediately got in my helicopter and went there and started communicating with the 5th
Lieutenant Colonel who was not in the fire base with the troop, but was some distance away in his headquarters.
And then I started communicating with a little cavalry troop commander.
It is very important that you maintain communication with them.
